item.title: By: Alan Brill
item.dc:creator: Alan Brill
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://kavvanah.wordpress.com/2012/05/30/moshe-halbertal-on-sacrifice/#comment-4693">zjb</a>.
He deals with Mauss in a single paragraph and turns the Christian connotations such as Jesus into scapegoat victim and Augustine into proto-Maimonidean Teshuvah. The book avoids many of the associations that come to our minds. It is strongest for the second part as a modern ethical statement, a textual application of Levinas as sacrfice.

item.title: By: zjb
item.dc:creator: zjb
item.description: Thanks, alan. Do you or anyone else think this might present a problem with the conceptualization of the book? To me, it's big difference. A sacrifice is one thing --the gift you give to God and sometimes get to eat. It's an object-phenomenon. But in English, it's loaded up with a lot of pious moralizing about the self. Devotion of soul (ok, a bad translation) has a different resonance to me, maybe because there is no precise equivalent in English. Please let me know if I'm not getting this right, or if this is worth pursuing.

item.title: By: zjb
item.dc:creator: zjb
item.description: I'm genuinely confused and hope someone can clarify something. Is "sacrifice"(korban, zevachim) the same thing in Hebrew as "mesirat nefesh," "kiddush ha'shem" or any other indigenous term for same? And if this is true in the medieval period (response to Crusader massacres), is it true of rabbinic literatures or biblical ones? I'm thinking "sacrifice for" might be a very bad concept for what MH is getting at, even if the link between one and the other makes intuitive sense in English.
